title: Ice Cream - Build Your Own

options.name: Standard Ice Cream Base
steps: Combine the sugar, dry milk powder, and xanthan gum in a small bowl and stir well.
Pour the corn syrup into a medium pot and stir in the whole milk.
Add the sugar mixture and immediately whisk vigorously until smooth.
Set the pot over medium heat and cook, stirring often and adjusting the heat if necessary to prevent a simmer, until the sugar has fully dissolved, about 3 minutes.
Remove the pot from the heat.
Add the cream and whisk until fully combined.
Transfer the mixture to an airtight container and refrigerate until well chilled, at least 6 hours, or for even better texture and flavor, 24 hours.
Stir the base back together if it separates during the resting time. The base can be stored in the fridge for up to 1 week or in the freezer for up to 3 months.

options.name: Blood Pudding

ingredients.name: unsweetened cocoa powder (preferably Guittard's Cocoa Rouge)

steps: In a small saucepan, combine the cream, blood, brandy, sugar, cocoa powder, cinnamon stick, salt, coriander seeds, and peppercorns. Thoroughly whisk the ingredients together.
Set the pan over medium-low heat and cook, stirring constantly, until the blood mixture thickens enough to coat the back of a spoon, about 8 minutes.
Toward the end, use an instant-read thermometer to ensure the mixture registers 160°F (71°C).
Remove the pan from the heat and let the mixture sit for 10 to 15 minutes to cool slightly and steep the spices.
Pour through a fine-mesh strainer into a container and discard the peppercorns, coriander seeds, and cinnamon stick.
Chill until cold and the mixture has a pudding-like consistency, about 3 hours. Use right away or store in the fridge with plastic wrap directly on the surface for up to 2 days.

options.name: Lavender Honey

ingredients.name: natural purple food coloring (optional, preferably India Tree brand)

steps: In a small saucepan, combine the water and honey. Bring the mixture to a boil, stirring occasionally, then take it off the heat.
Stir in the lavender, cover the saucepan, and let steep at room temperature for at least 4 hours or overnight.
Pour the syrup through a fine-mesh strainer into a container, pressing on the flower buds to extract as much liquid as possible.
Chill until cold and use right away, or refrigerate in an airtight container for up to 2 weeks.

ingredients.name: ice cream base, very cold (from above)

steps: Put the ice cream base and the flavor mixture into a bowl and use a stick blender to briefly blend to combine well.
Pour the mixture into an ice cream maker and turn on the machine.
Churn just until the mixture has the texture of soft-serve.
Transfer the ice cream into freezer-friendly containers.
Cover with parchment paper, pressing it to the surface of the ice cream so it adheres, then cover with a lid.
Store in the coldest part of your freezer (farthest from the door) until firm, at least 6 hours.
Ice cream will keep for up to 3 months.

notes: The base recipe yields a few more tablespoons than needed - this is intentional so you have enough even when some gets left behind in the pan or container.
For blood pudding: The flavor is a heady mix of spices, cocoa, and cream cooked into real blood pudding. It carefully toes the line between delectable and frightful.
Pig's blood can often be found frozen at Asian grocery stores or ordered from a butcher.
For lavender: Use culinary-grade dried lavender (pesticide-free) from the spice shop or a specialty store.
Always fully thaw frozen base before using.
For best texture, chill the base for 24 hours before churning.
